content: 10x10 (and any other even-sized board) is a trivial draw. If you mirror your opponent's moves, the grid fills symmetrically and the score is equal. Switching back to 9x9 should fix this. 9x9 had a strong bias for player 1 because they get an extra turn, but now there's a second round to balance the player 1 advantage which was added after the switch to 10x10. Since the winner is whoever gets the most points in both rounds combined, the game is balanced.

There is one very important thing missing from the statement. You should explain that, during a game, each player plays two matches with reversed colors in order to avoid the first player advantage and keep the game balanced. The final score is the sum of the points scored by each player during the two matches. 

Therefore, a bot should be able to restart with a fresh state. For instance, if the number of available moves is 100 (resp. 99), you have a new game and you are the first (resp. second) player. I found this was the easiest way for a proper restart detection.

Hello Waffle3z, another possibility is to put some aleatory even number of holes inside the grid (not symetrical) : more variety of boards and not an evident avantage for the first player as for odd sized board.

Starting with some moves already made would be needed on an even-sized board, but I would prefer the game being played from the beginning. Player 1 has an advantage on odd boards, so across the 2 rounds both players take turns exploiting their advantage to try to score the most points in total.

An odd size would not help as much as you think. Player 1 could  still mirror player 2 after starting in the center. Not sure if this guarantees a win, but it will at least guarantee a draw, which may be all you need if you are ahead after the first game.
It doesn't guarantee a win and it requires that you win as player 2 in the first game, which is harder, to force win by drawing the second.

Sure, but the entire second game automatically becomes useless as soon as p2 wins the first. That limits the usefulness of an odd board already. But if this is really all that it does, it would be ok and it would indeed be better than an even board.

However: Just because we don't see an easy way to use mirroring to decide the game on an odd board doesn't mean it doesn't exist. Perhaps there is a way you can reason out how to deal with the assymetry.

Before suggesting  this change with certainty, someone should try some math-y stuff to see if there isn't a way that odd boards can always be drawn also. Or... always be won by p1.  I haven't gotten into it enough to say either way.

If p1 mirrors p2's moves after going in the center, p2 can block the center from adding any points and force a draw. If p2 mirrors p1's moves then p1 can make sure the center is worth points and win. Mirroring is a loss for p2 and a draw for p1. If p2 wins on an odd board in the first round, it's likely they would also win the next round with the handicap reversed, so that's probably not a huge deal.

Yeah I thought so, but what if p1 doesn't mirror p2, but does something else. Something close to mirroring but better. It would be more complicated and have more options for p2 to be countered. Are you sure there isn't a way? Mirroring may just be suboptimal.

Perhaps you can only prove a win for p1, or a draw for p2 ultra-weakly as it is explained here: 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solved_game

In that case we would only know the end result on perfect play, which would be ok.
